ILLIAM the id 1î«, î«iled the Conâ queror, certainly could not have that Appellation from the winning one only Battle ; for his Viî» ory over Harold, and the taking of Dover, were his only military Exploits in England, before he was crown'd ; and theÅ¿e, had not the Cabals of the Clergy prevented the Deî®¢gns of Men zealous for their Country , he had found would rather have proved Snares, by animating him to puÅ¿h his PurÅ¿uits, as he would have had freÅ¿h Armies to encounter in an Enemy's Country, where he might have loî« his own, had not the EngliÅ¿h refuÅ¿ed to hazard a Å¿econd Battle. I Å¿ay, when one conî®¢ders the Situation of that Prince, his Viî» ory had proved rather a Snare than an Advantage, but for the Power of the Clergy ; and have Å¿hewn his Undertaking as raÅ¿h, as by the Intervention of the Churchmen, it proved fortunate. Wherefore, I am inclined to believe this Appellation of Conqueror was rather given him by the EngliÅ¿h, from the Manner of his treating his new Subjeî» s. At ï¬rî« he was tender of provoking them, exhorting his great Oï¬cers to treat them with Moderation, and Å¿everely puniÅ¿hing the Subalterns and Soldiers who gave them any juî« Grounds of Complaint ; but this did not prevent his Jealouî®¢es, and his taking all neceî®¦ary Precautions to Å¿ecure his Acquili tion. He immediately rewarded the Heads of his Folâ lowers out of Harold's TreaÅ¿ures, garriÅ¿on'd î«rong Towns, and carry'd into Normandy Å¿everal of the EngliÅ¿h Noâ bility.

Though William aï¬eî» ed to begin his Reign with Leâ nity, it was not long before the EngliÅ¿h were made Å¿enâ î®¢ble, by his Regents, whom he left, on returning to Normandy, that they were deem'd a conquer'd People ; for theÅ¿e Regents either abuÅ¿ed their Authority, to enrich themÅ¿elves and Creatures, or follow'd the Orders William had given them, to provoke the EngliÅ¿h to rebel, that he might have ah Opportunity to puniÅ¿h and empoveriÅ¿h them ; î«rengthen himÅ¿elf, by dividing their Eî«ates among his Normans, and, farther, by their Spoils, to diÅ¿charge the heavy Debt he had contraî» ed for his Expedition, which he had no Way to pay oï¬, but by î«ripping the EngliÅ¿h. The InÅ¿ults which the Conquer'd daily Å¿uï¬er'd ; the King's JealouÅ¿y, increaÅ¿ed by two fruitleÅ¿s Attempts to Å¿hake oï¬ the Norman Yoke ; his Wants and avaritious Temper, could not but breed ill Blood between him and his Subjeî» s of England, whoÅ¿e Murmurings made him reÅ¿olve to eî«abliÅ¿h the Authority he had gain'd, by whatâ ever Means, whether conÅ¿onant or not with Juî«ice ; wheâ ther agreeable or not to the People, and by the Revival of Daneâgelt, which was exaî» ed with the utmoî« Rigour, reminded them of their former MiÅ¿eries under the Tyâ ranny of that Nation. This, and other Methods to raiÅ¿e Money, occaî®¢on'd Revolts ; Revolts, Severities. The Normans were carreÅ¿s'd , and the EngliÅ¿h little better treated than Slaves. VÃ¦ Viî» is. The Poï¿½ts of Honour and Proï¬ï¿½, with the Eî«ates of the latter, were given to the former ; the Clergy, who had, we may Å¿ay, given him the Crown, were not exempted. The King cancell'd the Immunities granted them by his Predeceî®¦ors ; Soldiers were quarter'd upon their Monalleries , which were plunder'd of their Money and Plate ; their Abbots, nay, and BiÅ¿hops were depoÅ¿ed, to make Room for Normans. But what was yet a greater Proof of their Slavery, the innocent EngliÅ¿h were puniÅ¿h'd for the Crimes of the Norâ mans, and were alÅ¿o turn'd out of their Dwellings, their Churches and Villages demoliÅ¿h'd, to become a Receptacle for Bealls. In a Word, he was jealous of, hated, deÅ¿â piÅ¿ed the EngliÅ¿h, and treated them with the greateî« Seâ verity, putting out their Eyes, cutting oï¬ their Hands and Feet, î«arving them to Death, and impriÅ¿oning them for Life ; uÅ¿ual PuniÅ¿hments for Å¿mall Crimes. Yet he obtain'd the Crown rather by the Gift of the People, inâ î®£uenced by the Clergy, than by Force of Arms ; though 'tis not impoî®§ble he might deem their Submiî®§on the Eï¬eî» of Cowardice, and from thence hold them as Obâ jeî» s of Contempt ; think he had no Obligation to a People whoÅ¿e Fears, alone, had given him Poî®¦eî®§on of the Throne, and alÅ¿o, for that ReaÅ¿on, judge it his Right of Conqueî«.

It may be Å¿aid, that this Treatment was no more than what the EngliÅ¿h merited for their Folly, in not having made Terms on their Submiî®§on. Though we ï¬nd not what Terms the Clergy made, yet we may conclude that they inî®¢î«ed on Å¿ome, eÅ¿pecially for themÅ¿elves. But did

this avail them any thing, when William was in Poî®¦eÅ¿â î®¢on of the Kingdom ? Conditions which Sovereigns make with their Subjeî» s are not always regarded by the former, and who, among the latter, dare undertake to exï¿½î» the ObÅ¿ervance of them, though violated in the moî« ï¬agrant Manner ? Such a Step would be a Rebellion, and he who took it, together with his Adherents, would undergo the Fate of Traitors, if they had not Power to oblige the Prince to do them Juî«ice ; and when that has been the CaÅ¿e, they have commonly exceeded the Bounds of their ï¬rî« Pretenî®¢ons ; Å¿hewn as little Regard for their Allegiance as the Sovereign had for his Engagements : and were as unjuî« in encroaching on the Prerogatives of the Crown, as the Monarch had been in his Endeavours to extend them over the Privileges and Liberties of the People. The Power the Barons formerly had, enabled them to exaî» of their Kings the Performance of Conditions, but that Power did not exiî« in the Time of the Conqueror, and the Struggles the EngliÅ¿h made in his Time only increaÅ¿ed the Weight of their Burden, and riveted their Fetters. A King who has a î«anding Army, and has any Regard to the Conditions on which he received the Crown, gives a rare Example of Juî«ice and Moderation ; but Å¿hould he treat them as a weak Impoî®¢tion, how would the People be redreÅ¿s'd ? Their Murmurs might (if ever they came to his Ears) acquaint him with their DiÅ¿content, but, at the Å¿ame time, they would proclaim their WeakneÅ¿s, excite his Contempt, awake his Vigilance ; occaî®¢on his Diï¬â dence, and increaÅ¿e their Misfortunes, by making them purchaÅ¿e, at a dearer Rate, the Chains he deî®¢gn'd them. I allow the Å¿eeing of Strangers, Subjeî» s of a Province of France, prefer'd to the EngliÅ¿h ; to Å¿ee theÅ¿e Strangers look down with Contempt upon them ; themÅ¿elves turn'd out of Poï¿½ls and of their Ellates, to make Koom for Norâ mans, muî« be very galling ; but when we conî®¢der that they brought theÅ¿e InÅ¿ults, and other MisÅ¿ortunes, upon themÅ¿elves, by inconî®¢derately bowing their Necks to reâ ceive the Yoke of a Å¿oreign Prince, we can Å¿carce aî®¦ord our Pity to the Calamities they experienced. But to return to Condiâ tions between Prince and People.

Let us Å¿uppoÅ¿e what our Anceî«ors Å¿uÅ¿fer'd was our own CaÅ¿e, which it never can be under the Dominion of a Prince of EngliÅ¿h Blood, (though a Foreigner) who has gain'd the Hearts of his People, by his Wiï¿½dom, Juî«ice, Moderation and Bravery ; but, I Å¿ay, let us Å¿uppoÅ¿e that

he could be capable of aweing us into a ï¬aviÅ¿h Submiî®§on, by making the Conï¬dence we have repoÅ¿ed in him the Means of doing it ; exaî» what Sums he pleaÅ¿ed ; make his Army his Colleî» ors ; revive the Corvï¿½eï¿½feu, corruptly the Curfew, and, on our murmuring, turn the EngliÅ¿h not only out of their Poî«s but Ellates, and Å¿ubî«itute Hâns ; treat the EngliÅ¿h with Contempt, and mention them with Hatred ; that we were diî«inguiÅ¿h'd, by even the meaneî« Servants among the Hâns, as a moî« deÅ¿picable People, ï¬t only to be employ'd under them in the moî« Å¿ervile Oï¬ces, and, if carry'd into the Field, proper only to receive the ï¬rî« Fire of the Enemy, placed as Screens, and dellined to be Food for Gunpowder, and to ï¬ll up Ditches, as Sir John Falî«aï¬ Å¿ays, could we be tax'd with Want of having made our Conditions ? It is certain we could not, and as certain, that we owe the Bleî®§ngs we now enjoy under his Majeî«y, to his great WiÅ¿dom, Juî«ice and Moderation, not to our Precaution. For the Experience we have had of his Royal Virtues wrought on us to inveî« him with the Power to treat us as the Conqueror did our Anceî«ors. But we had a Security which can never fail us ; the Regard his Mây has to his own Honour, and that UprightneÅ¿s obÅ¿ervable in all his Aî» iors.
